Column Comment.0: UNIQUE WELL IDENTIFIER: A unique name, code or number designated as theprimary key for this row.
Column Comment.1: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.2: TUBING TYPE: This reference table describes the particular type of tubular or type.For example tubing, casing or liner. This is a general classification. A more specificdescription can be found in R_LINER_TYPE.
Column Comment.3: TUBING OBSERVATION NUMBER: Number uniquely identifying each pipe string ofdecreasing size run in the well.
Column Comment.4: CEMENT OBSERVATION NUMBER: Number uniquely identifying each cement jobperformed in the well. When more than one job is performed on the same date, thisnumber may be used to assign the sequence of operations.
Column Comment.5: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.6: CEMENT AMOUNT: Value for the volume or mass of cement used in a cementingoperation.
Column Comment.7: CEMENT AMOUNT OUOM: Cement amount original unit of measure.
Column Comment.8: CEMENT AMOUNT UNIT: Cement amount unit of measure.
Column Comment.9: CEMENT BUSINESS ASSOCIATE: The name of the business associate whoperformed the cementing operation.
Column Comment.10: CEMENT TYPE: The particular type of cement (and additive) used during acementing operation.
Column Comment.11: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.12: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.13: PERFORATION BASE DEPTH: Base depth of the perforated interval for the squeezecementing job. The squeeze cement operation pumps cement slurry under pressuredown the well and through perforations in the casing to fill channels behindthecasing.
Column Comment.14: PERFORATION BASE DEPTH ORIGINAL UNITS OF MEASURE
Column Comment.15: PERFORATION COUNT: Number of perforations or holes pierced through the casingto perform the squeeze cementing job.
Column Comment.16: PERFORATION PER UNIT OF MEASURE: Identifies the measurement used for theperforation interval. Combined with PERFORATION_COUNT indicates the number ofperforations per interval.
Column Comment.17: PERFORATION TOP DEPTH: Top depth of the perforated interval for the squeezecementing job. The squeeze cement operation pumps cement slurry under pressuredown the well and through perforations in the casing to fill channels behind thecasing.
Column Comment.18: PERFORATION TOP DEPTH ORIGINAL UNITS OF MEASURE
Column Comment.19: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.20: RECEMENT INDICATOR: Code to indicate if the cement operation is a second orsubsequent operation for the same purpose and at the same depth. A recementoperation may be performed if tests fail to confirm the integrity of the initial cementjob.
Column Comment.21: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.22: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.23: STAGE NUMBER: Number assigned to each application (stage) of cement suppliedto secure the casing, in sequence.
Column Comment.24: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.25: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.26: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.27: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.28: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.29: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.30: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
